hypothesis.name: Mid-Range Tilt and Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of around 30° is often optimal for solar panels in temperate regions, combined with an azimuth of 180° (south-facing) to maximize exposure to sunlight.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt for Winter Optimization
hypothesis.rationale: A higher tilt angle of 60° can be beneficial in winter months to capture lower sun angles, paired with a south-facing azimuth.

hypothesis.name: Low Tilt for Summer Optimization
hypothesis.rationale: A lower tilt angle of 15° may be more effective during summer months, allowing for better sunlight capture when the sun is high in the sky.

hypothesis.name: East-West Orientation
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring an azimuth of 90° (east) and 270° (west) can help understand the impact of morning and evening sunlight on energy production.

hypothesis.name: Max Capacity Exploration
hypothesis.rationale: Testing the upper limit of system capacity (20 kW) with a moderate tilt and azimuth to assess the impact of increased capacity on energy production.

hypothesis.name: Optimized Mid-Tilt and Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: Building on the highest observed energy output, this hypothesis focuses on a tilt of 45° and a south-facing azimuth to maximize solar exposure.

hypothesis.name: Slightly Higher Tilt Exploration
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring a slightly higher tilt of 46° to see if it can yield even better energy production while maintaining a south-facing azimuth.

hypothesis.name: Lower Tilt with Higher Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a lower tilt of 40° with a higher system capacity of 20 kW to assess if increased capacity can compensate for the lower tilt.

hypothesis.name: Eastward Orientation with Moderate Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring an azimuth of 90° with a moderate tilt of 45° to evaluate the potential of morning sunlight on energy production.

hypothesis.name: High Capacity with Optimal Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: Testing the maximum system capacity of 20 kW with a tilt of 45° and azimuth of 180° to see if this combination can yield the highest energy output.
